title: Godly Sorrow and Comfort
shortSummary: In 2 Corinthians 7, Paul encourages believers to pursue holiness by cleansing themselves from sin and living in reverent fear of God. He expresses joy over the Corinthians' godly sorrow that led to repentance, highlighting the comfort and renewed fellowship brought by Titus' visit and their restored obedience.
timeline: c. AD 55 - Paul's Second Epistle to the Corinthians during his Third Missionary Journey

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle and author of this letter, who writes to encourage and comfort the Corinthian church, expressing his deep pastoral concern and joy over their repentance.

keyCharacters.name: Titus
keyCharacters.description: Paul’s trusted companion who brought encouraging news of the Corinthians' repentance and obedience, serving as a source of comfort to Paul.

keyCharacters.name: The Corinthians
keyCharacters.description: The recipients of Paul's letter, a church that experienced correction and responded with godly sorrow and renewed obedience.

definitions.definition: Moral impurity or defilement of both body and spirit, referring to sin that contaminates a believer’s life.
A sincere, Spirit-led remorse over sin that leads to repentance and salvation, distinct from worldly sorrow which leads to death.
The ongoing process of becoming more like Christ by removing sin and growing in reverence toward God.
A heartfelt turning away from sin and turning toward God, resulting in a changed life.

outline.heading: Exhortation to Holiness and Integrity
outline.description: Paul urges believers to cleanse themselves from all moral and spiritual impurity, emphasizing holiness motivated by the fear of God and affirming his sincere love and integrity toward the Corinthians.

outline.heading: Paul’s Comfort Amid Trials
outline.description: Despite external conflicts and internal fears, Paul finds comfort through Titus’ arrival and the encouraging report of the Corinthians’ earnestness and repentance.

outline.heading: The Blessing of Godly Sorrow
outline.description: Paul explains the difference between worldly sorrow and godly sorrow, rejoicing that the Corinthians’ sorrow led to repentance and spiritual renewal, demonstrating genuine transformation.

outline.heading: Purpose of Paul’s Previous Letter
outline.description: Paul clarifies that his earlier letter was written out of pastoral concern to reveal his care for the Corinthians before God, rejoicing in their obedience and the renewed fellowship evidenced by Titus’ refreshed spirit.

application: Pursue holiness by regularly examining and cleansing your life from sin, motivated by reverence for God.
Embrace godly sorrow when confronted with sin, allowing it to lead you to genuine repentance and spiritual growth.
Find comfort in the fellowship of believers, especially in times of trial, and encourage one another toward obedience.
Respond to correction with humility and zeal, demonstrating a heart aligned with God’s purposes.

keyVerses.text: Having therefore these promises, dearly beloved, let us cleanse ourselves from all filthiness of the flesh and spirit, perfecting holiness in the fear of God.
keyVerses.significance: This verse sets the tone for the chapter, emphasizing the call to holiness and spiritual purity grounded in God’s promises.

keyVerses.text: For godly sorrow worketh repentance to salvation not to be repented of: but the sorrow of the world worketh death.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the vital difference between godly sorrow that leads to salvation and worldly sorrow that leads to spiritual death.

keyVerses.text: Therefore we were comforted in your comfort: yea, and exceedingly the more joyed we for the joy of Titus, because his spirit was refreshed by you all.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the mutual encouragement and joy that comes from restored fellowship and obedience within the body of Christ.
